intro: Machaeranthera coloradoensis var. brandegeei, commonly known as the Colorado prickly poppy, is a perennial herb native to the western United States. It is characterized by its spiny stems and showy, yellow-orange flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is found in arid and semi-arid regions. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered with fine hairs, while its flowers have five petals and numerous stamens. This variety is part of the Papaveraceae family and is adapted to withstand harsh environmental conditions.
